text: One of the things that we also know is it's not just the big huge superstars who have those rabid and super engaged fan bases. People are really passionate just about supporting the artists that they love in general.
speaker: Camille Hearst
context: Lenny inquires about Camille's role at Spotify as head of fan monetization. Camille explains that her team focuses on developing new ways to facilitate connections between artists and their fans. She emphasizes that even lesser-known artists have dedicated supporters and that Spotify aims to transform this enthusiasm into monetization opportunities for the artists.
text_ko: 우리가 아는 것 중 하나는, 정말 유명한 슈퍼스타들만 열정적인 팬층을 가지고 있는 게 아니라는 거예요. 사람들은 자신이 좋아하는 아티스트를 지원하는 데 정말 열정적이에요.
text_zh: 我们知道，不仅仅是那些大牌明星拥有狂热且高度参与的粉丝群体。人们对支持他们喜爱的艺术家普遍充满热情。
text_es: Una de las cosas que también sabemos es que no son solo las grandes superestrellas las que cuentan con bases de fans tan apasionadas y comprometidas. La gente realmente siente una gran pasión por apoyar a los artistas que aman en general.

text: To some degree, there has to be a value exchange that happens in order for a creative person to live from their art.
speaker: Camille Hearst
context: Lenny asks Camille about the best and worst parts of working with artists. Camille reflects on the difficulty artists face in wanting to share their work for free due to their passion for their craft. She highlights the necessity of a value exchange, meaning that artists need to receive compensation for their work to sustain their livelihoods.
text_ko: 어느 정도는 창작자가 자신의 예술로 살아가기 위해서 가치 교환이 필요해요.
text_zh: 在某种程度上，创意人士必须进行价值交换，才能通过他们的艺术谋生。
text_es: En cierta medida, debe existir un intercambio de valor para que una persona creativa pueda vivir de su arte.

text: But I do think that this area continues to be untapped. I just don't see a world where... I think of Michelle Phan, right? She's basically a mini Disney and when you think of it like that, she's created IP.
speaker: Camille Hearst
context: Lenny prompts Camille to discuss the future of the creator economy. Camille argues that the potential for creators to thrive is far from exhausted, using the example of Michelle Phan, a successful content creator who has built a personal brand akin to a mini Disney. She emphasizes that creating intellectual property (IP) opens doors for various revenue streams and opportunities for creators.
text_ko: 하지만 이 분야는 여전히 개발되지 않은 것 같아요. 저는 그런 세상이 있다고 생각하지 않아요... 미셸 판(Michelle Phan)을 생각해보면, 그녀는 사실상 미니 디즈니(mini Disney 같은 존재잖아요. 그렇게 생각하면, 그녀는 IP(지식재산권)를 만들어낸 거죠.
text_zh: 但我确实认为这个领域仍然有待开发。我无法想象一个世界……我想到米歇尔·潘（Michelle Phan），对吧？她基本上就是一个迷你迪士尼，当你这样想的时候，她实际上创造了知识产权（IP）。
text_es: Pero creo que esta área sigue sin explotar. Simplemente no veo un mundo en el que... Pienso en Michelle Phan, ¿verdad? Ella es básicamente un mini Disney y, al pensarlo así, ha creado propiedad intelectual (IP).

text: I think it was probably predictable to some degree that platforms would win because just of the nature of aggregation.
speaker: Camille Hearst
context: Lenny asks Camille about the trajectory of the creator economy and platforms. Camille reflects on the strong network effect that comes from aggregation, meaning that once a platform consolidates enough creators or consumers, it becomes difficult for new entrants to compete. She notes that established platforms are strategically enhancing features to retain creators and prevent them from leaving.
text_ko: 플랫폼이 이길 거라는 건 어느 정도 예측 가능했을 것 같아요. 결국 집합의 특성 때문이죠.
text_zh: 我认为，平台的胜出在某种程度上是可以预见的，因为这与聚合的本质有关。
text_es: Creo que era predecible hasta cierto punto que las plataformas ganarían debido a la naturaleza de la agregación.

text: So one of the things that I've seen that I don't know if people realize is consistency and predictability of content creation.
speaker: Camille Hearst
context: Lenny asks Camille about important factors for success in the creator economy. Camille points out that consistency and predictability in content creation are crucial for creators to build an audience. She compares this to the concept of putting in '10,000 hours' to master a skill, indicating that regular output helps creators improve and connect with their audience.
text_ko: 제가 본 것 중 하나는 사람들이 잘 인식하지 못하는 부분인데, 콘텐츠 제작에서 일관성과 예측 가능성이 정말 중요하다는 거예요.
text_zh: 我观察到的一个方面是，内容创作的一致性和可预测性，很多人可能并没有意识到这一点。
text_es: Una de las cosas que he observado y que no sé si la gente se da cuenta es la importancia de la consistencia y la predictibilidad en la creación de contenido.

text: What I learned and that we really emphasized during that time is this idea of having dual track agile going where you're doing discovery and delivery simultaneously.
speaker: Camille Hearst
context: Lenny asks Camille about her favorite frameworks for building products. Camille discusses the 'dual track agile' methodology, which involves conducting discovery (research and validation of ideas) and delivery (actual product development) at the same time. This approach helps teams de-risk assumptions and innovate effectively while responding to user needs.
text_ko: 그때 제가 배운 것 중 하나는 동시에 탐색(discovery)과 전달(delivery)을 진행하는 이중 트랙(dual track) 애자일의 중요성이에요.
text_zh: 我在那段时间学到的，并且我们非常强调的，就是同时进行探索（discovery）和交付（delivery）的双轨敏捷（dual track agile）理念。
text_es: Lo que aprendí y que realmente enfatizamos durante ese tiempo es esta idea de tener un enfoque ágil de doble vía, donde se realiza la exploración (discovery) y la entrega (delivery) de manera simultánea.
